ns0:entry.ns0:title: [TED]The Emerging Science of Finding Critical Metals | Mfikeyi Makayi | TED

ns2:group.ns2:title: The Emerging Science of Finding Critical Metals | Mfikeyi Makayi | TED
ns2:group.ns2:description:
Your smartphone, computer and electric car all depend on one thing â€” critical minerals buried deep underground. But thereâ€™s a catch: the mining industry has gotten dramatically worse at discovering new deposits just when we need them most, says mining innovator Mfikeyi Makayi. She introduces new AI-powered technology that could fix this problem by predicting mineral locations 10,000 times faster than conventional methods and transforming an industry essential to a sustainable future. (Recorded at TED Countdown Summit 2025 on June 18, 2025)

ns0:entry.ns0:title: [The Verge]The Sony Watchman was must-see TV | Version History

ns2:group.ns2:title: The Sony Watchman was must-see TV | Version History
ns2:group.ns2:description:
1982's coolest gadget was the Sony Watchman portable TV. Decades before everyone was glued to YouTube on their smartphones, the Watchman popularized the concept of video on the go. In the early days of the personal-tech revolution, youâ€™d find the Watchman antennas up everywhere from the church pew to the baseball bleacher. Victoria Song and Allison Johnson join David Pierce to dive into the engineering feat that made the first Watchman possible. #Podcast #Technology #Nostalgia
0:00 Introduction to the Watchman 00:58 Meet the Hosts 02:13 Nostalgia and Personal TV Memories 04:52 The Evolution of Portable TVs 10:55 The Birth of the Watchman 17:13 Technical Innovations and Features 25:28 Market Reception and Cultural Impact 29:35 The Rise and Fall of the Sony Watchman 30:40 The Watchman as a Cultural Icon 33:39 The Watchman in Pop Culture and Personal Stories 39:20 The Decline of the Watchman 41:38 Version History Questions 56:34 Final Thoughts and Conclusion

ns2:group.ns2:title: Why Building New Proteins from Scratch Is Our New Superpower | David Baker | TED
ns2:group.ns2:description:
The rapidly evolving field of protein design is revealing solutions to some of the worldâ€™s greatest problems, whether it's blocking a virus, breaking down a pollutant or creating brand-new materials. In conversation with TEDâ€™s Whitney Pennington Rodgers, biochemist David Baker explores his teamâ€™s Nobel Prize-winning work using AI to design new proteins with functions never before seen in nature â€” achieving breakthroughs that have fundamentally changed the future of science. (This conversation was part of an exclusive TED Membership event. TED Membership is the best way to support and engage with the big ideas you love from TED. To learn more, visit ted.com/membership.) (Recorded at TED Membership on June 11, 2025)

ns0:entry.ns0:title: [Amazon Web Services]Enhancing NFL Player Health and Safety with AWS | Amazon Web Services

ns2:group.ns2:title: Enhancing NFL Player Health and Safety with AWS | Amazon Web Services
ns2:group.ns2:description:
AWS OnAir's Nick Betz travelled to Philadelphia for the 2025 NFL Season Kickoff to learn how AWS and the NFL team up to continuously innovate in the world of football. In this clip, Nick meets with Mackenzie Herzog from the NFL to discuss how the NFL and AWS team up every year with technology like the Digital Athlete to make the game safer for players.
You can learn more about the Digital Athlete here: https://awsonair.net/Digital-Athlete
